title: "Utah Curls" Might Replace Your Beach-Wave Obsession
description: If your TikTok FYP is anything like mine, it's probably filled with beauty-centric posts. Any time I'm scrolling the app, I can guarantee I'll learn about a new skin-care product, a fun nail trend, or an easy hair hack (with the occasional tarot card reader telling me my ex-boyfriend is thinking of me sprinkled in). The app has helped me master how to create the perfect winged eyeliner on downturned eyes, how to get a voluminous ponytail, and how to nail the best "my lips but better" makeup combo. Recently, I've been seeing everyone on the app going bananas over "Utah curls." At first glance, I didn't really see what the big deal was, but after seeing countless videos over the last month, and spending a few hours Googling, "what are Utah curls?" it was clear that I needed to try them out. The curls are loose, bouncy, and different from your run-of-the-mill beach wave. Keep scrolling to learn more about the hair trend, find out how you can do it at home, and see what my results were after trying it out for myself. What Are Utah Curls? @sydneyjcutler Since it pains me to see yâ€™all restraightening your ends ğŸ˜© #hairtutorial #hairtok #utahhair #utahcurls #utah â™¬ original sound - Syd So, what are Utah Curls? At first glance, they might just look like your average beachy wave, but they're actually a bit different. One key difference is that Utah curls have straight ends, whereas beachy waves don't. Also, beachy waves can usually be achieved using any kind of hot tool - such as a wand, a curling iron, or even a flat iron - but to get Utah curls right, you need a curling iron with a clamp. How to Get Utah Curls If you're a beginner to using a curling iron, it might take a bit to master. I'm pretty adept with mine, but this took even me a few tries to get right. To start, you want dry, preferably smooth hair that has been blown out. Next, I used the Drybar Hot Toddy Heat Protectant Mist ($29) all over my head. If you're using hot tools, you absolutely need a heat protectant. I love this one because you can use it on dry hair without getting that wet feeling. After dividing it into sections, I took the T3 SinglePass 1 in Curling Iron ($170) and began curling. I've tested a lot of curling irons over the years, but this is the one I always go back to. It's the best option for beachy waves, loose waves, and everything in between (and ultimately I think it's what made my Utah curls look their best). If you're trying to achieve the look at home, your best bet is looking for an instructional video. In my opinion, it's a lot easier to watch and try to replicate the movement than follow a written tutorial. I started by clamping my hair with the iron about mid-way down and then curled upward, away from my face. However, the key to Utah curls isn't how you curl, it's how you unravel. While unwrapping, I twisted the curling iron underneath and behind the strand of hair. When I got to the ends, I dragged down to make sure they were straight. Immediately after each curl, I made sure to let it cool in the shape it was in. Once my entire head was finished, I brushed through the ends with a wide-tooth comb. The tutorial I watched said to use a light-hold hairspray and even some hair paste, but I opted to forgo additional products entirely. My Utah Curls Results Overall, I liked my Utah curls, but they weren't my favorite hairstyle. I'm much more into a sleek, bouncy blowout achieved with my Dyson Airwrap, but this worked for me - especially for a second-day look. I think this hairstyle looks best on medium-length to super-long hair. I've seen it done on short hair, but in my opinion, it doesn't quite have the same effect, especially if the hair is layered. Renee Rodriguez (she/her) is a staff writer and social producer for PS. She writes across all verticals, but her main areas of expertise focus on fashion and beauty content with an emphasis on reviews and editor experiments. She also produces social content for the PS TikTok and Instagram accounts.

title: I Tried the Upside-Down Hair-Washing Trick That's All Over TikTok
description: I've washed my hair countless times, but I've never considered changing the way that I did it. I've always rinsed, shampooed, rinsed, conditioned, and rinsed one last time. Why fix what's not broken, right? But TikTok has other ideas. One night, I stumbled across a video on upside-down hair washing, in which the creator shared her hair-care routine that included shampooing and conditioning her head in the shower upside down. When I told the rest of the beauty team about this strange hair-washing technique, all but one person - who regularly follows this hack, as well as the reverse hair-washing technique herself - were just as surprised as I was. The reasoning for doing this, so I'm told, is to help add volume and body to any hair type - especially if it's fine. And as someone who fits that description, I was game to try it. The next time I showered, instead of using my shampoo and conditioner the way I've done it for the past two-plus decades, I flipped my head upside down. First, I'll say this: in order to pull off upside-down hair washing, you absolutely need a detachable shower head with a hose. But even with that, it's no easy task. The entire practice felt very strange - water gets everywhere if you're not careful. I used my Balmain Homme Treatment Bodyfying Shampoo ($72) and Balmain Homme Treatment Bodyfying Conditioner ($87) for the process, which already boast volumizing ingredients. With my head upside down and the shower nozzle dangling quite frantically, I lathered the roots of my hair, concentrating the shampoo on my scalp and not really worrying about washing my ends. Once that step was done, still with my head upside down (water in my ears, and soap in my eyes. . .), I rinsed the shampoo out. Using my conditioner next, I focused on the ends of my hair this time, avoiding my roots - something I do when I wash my hair right side up, too, to keep from weighing my hair down. After giving my head one final rinse, I was finished with the entire upside-down hair-washing process. It definitely took me longer than usual to do, but my hair surprisingly already felt softer to the touch, which gave me hope. Out of the shower, I put my hair up in a towel to dry a little bit before putting in a styling cream and blasting it with some heat (also while upside down - are you sensing a theme?). Already, my hair looked fluffier and had more volume, especially at the roots, which usually lay flat against my head. Because at this point I looked a little bit like a poodle that just got blow-dried, I decided to curl my hair with my Mermade Waver to see how that'd look. This is where the magic really happened. My hair retained its volume and had so much more bounce than it usually does. Despite being chaotic to do, upside-down hair washing really did give my fine hair next-level body, and the result was long lasting. This is definitely a trick I'll keep up my sleeve for days when I plan on heat styling in the future. Jessica Harrington (she/her) is the senior editor of PS Beauty, where she oversees coverage around makeup, skin care, hair, tattoos, and more. With more than eight years of industry experience, she has interviewed countless celebrities, reported on hundreds of beauty trends, and swatched more lipsticks than she can count. Prior to PS, Jessica worked for publications such as Makeup.com, Skincare.com, and The Zoe Report.

title: â€œWellnessâ€ Nails To Navy Blue: 12 Nail Trends That Are Going To Reign In 2025
description: The year might not be over just yet but with my New Yearâ€™s Eve nails all booked, Iâ€™m looking ahead to 2025 to collect ideas for my January manicure. And while 2024 has more than delivered on amazing trends to take inspiration from (Iâ€™m talking glass nails, chrome manicures and fresh takes on French tips), Iâ€™m glad to report that next year looks even better when it comes to incredible nail looks. Whether youâ€™re into a minimalist manicure or bedazzled nail art with all the trimmings, 2025 looks set to deliver on color, texture and nail health. But donâ€™t take my word for it. I caught up with some of the best nail artists in the business to get their predictions on what lies ahead for our nails next year. Hereâ€™s all the inspiration you need. Wellness Nails View this post on Instagram A post shared by Harriet Westmoreland (@harrietwestmoreland) The â€œclean girlâ€ nail aesthetic has been one of the most enduring nail trends of the last couple of years but in 2025 weâ€™ll see it go one step further with a focus on nail health. â€œNail care is evolving, with a focus on health-conscious products that support and protect natural nails,â€ says Juanita Huber-Millet, founder and creative director of Townhouse. â€œFrom breathable polishes to strengthening treatments, consumers are seeking out products designed to provide a nourishing, wellness-led experience that support natural nail growth.â€ Manucuristâ€™s Active Glow in Raspberry, $19, is a 2-in-1 treatment polish that leaves nails with a rosy sheen while nourishing them with sweet almond oil and raspberry extract. Navy Blue View this post on Instagram A post shared by Julia Diogo (@paintedbyjools) All the nail experts are in agreement: Navy blue will be on everyoneâ€™s nails in 2025. â€œBlues in general will be popular but navy will continue to be a standout color for the upcoming seasons,â€ says session manicurist Ami Streets. â€œItâ€™s a chic, deep hue that looks great as an edgier manicure color while still being softer and more elegant than black.â€ Julia Diogoâ€™s perfectly executed navy nails are timeless. Try Chanel Le Vernis Nail Color in 127 Fugueuse, $32, for a luxurious at-home manicure. Milky Pastels View this post on Instagram A post shared by Julia Diogo (@paintedbyjools) Thereâ€™s nothing new about pastels, especially in spring and summer, so itâ€™s no surprise that all the experts I spoke to predicted theyâ€™ll make a resurgence next year. However, 2025â€™s iteration is going to be more pared-back than ever. â€œAs we move into spring, Iâ€™m expecting milky shades that provide a fresh, [clean] aesthetic to be popular as they look effortlessly beautiful and put-together,â€ predicts international nail artist and one of Bio Sculptureâ€™s top technicians, Julia Diogo. Her soft lavender manicure in Bio Sculpture Fluttering Lavender, $13, fits the aesthetic perfectly.Â  Marble Elements View this post on Instagram A post shared by San Sung Kim | á„€á…µá†·á„‰á…¡á†«á„‰á…¥á†¼ (@sansungnails) Streets has marbling pinned as a nail trend thatâ€™s set to take off in 2025. â€œMarbling inspired by natural events like the sunrise, skies or the ocean works really well interpreted into nail art looks, so I think this trend will be one to watch,â€ she says. This marbled take on a sunset by San Sung Kim is so beautiful that it might just be first on my new year manicure wish list.Â  Tiffany Blue View this post on Instagram A post shared by Jaz (@paintbyjaz) Call it Tiffany blue, turquoise or aqua, this holiday-ready cyan might just be the breakout shade of 2025. Diogo notes the influence of â€œTiffany blue taking over recent catwalksâ€ as an indicator of whatâ€™s to come, while Streets talks of â€œaqua blues and greens inspired by the ocean with opalescent or shimmering finishesâ€ emerging as popular choices next year. OPIâ€™s Nail Lacquer in My Dogsled is a Hybrid, $11.99, is a similar sea green to the one used in Jazâ€™s minimalist double French manicure. Velvet Shine View this post on Instagram A post shared by Queenie Nguyen | elevated nail artist (@nailartbyqueenie) Texture is going to be huge next year and velvet finishes look set to adorn everyoneâ€™s nails. â€œTexture is really going to take centre stage in 2025 and velvet delivers on both depth and dimension,â€ explains Huber-Millet. â€œItâ€™s a subtle yet impactful design that will appeal to those who like more intricate details over ostentatious embellishments.â€ Queenie Nguyenâ€™s cinnamon velvet nails make for the perfect cosy fall and winter look. Recreate it at home with Beauty Pieâ€™s Wondercolor Nail Polish in Bright Bronze, $14. Micro French View this post on Instagram A post shared by CORRINNA BIANCA | LONDON (@corrinnabianca) Not all of 2025â€™s nail trends are going to be new; there are plenty of manicure looks that have proved popular this year that experts think will stick around for the long haul. â€œMinimalist nail art isnâ€™t going anywhere,â€ declares pro nail artist and educator Jessica White. â€œDesigns like micro French tips have become staples because theyâ€™re wearable and versatile.â€ Corrinna Biancaâ€™s cold brew latte French tips are so delicately painted and chic. Try it yourself (with a steady hand!) using Essie Nail Polish in Odd Squad, $11.10. Three-Dimensional View this post on Instagram A post shared by Melanie Graves (@overglowedit) Diogo is unequivocal about one thing for 2025: Itâ€™s all about dimension. â€œ3D nail art was one of the biggest trends of 2024 and I have no doubt that it will continue to dominate in 2025,â€ she says. â€œIâ€™m absolutely loving 3D swirls and outlines right now. Itâ€™s a great option for anyone who wants to try something a little playful.â€ Melanie Graves has shared so many amazing multidimensional manicures this year, but this monochromatic look is particularly cool. Fine Embellishment View this post on Instagram A post shared by Wendy (@mydumbnails) While 3D texture and nail decorations will continue to trend, Streets predicts a shift towards a more minimalist approach to adornment in 2025. â€œEmbellishments will stillÂ be super popular but I think that these will be toned down in favor of more refined adornments like pearls and crystals,â€ she explains. Wendyâ€™s shimmering manicure is both pretty and pared back. Get your hands on Pueen Nail Charms Multi Shapes Nail Art Kit, $5.74, which contains so many beautiful pearls and gems, to create your own version at home. Rich Burgundy View this post on Instagram A post shared by Lauren âœ¨ (@lolo.nailedit) While linen pastels and milky hues will take off for spring, we can still expect to see deep, rich shades reign supreme in 2025. This yearâ€™s obsession with chocolate brown will continue but weâ€™ll see a shift towards merlot and burgundy, as illustrated by Laurenâ€™s sultry red manicure. â€œBurgundy is going to remain a favorite in 2025,â€ confirms Diogo. â€œIâ€™m noticing a lot of buzz around Bio Sculptureâ€™s new Ghost Noir polish [available to licensed professionals only] which is nearly black with deep red undertones for a mysterious yet sophisticated vibe.â€ Celestial Yellow View this post on Instagram A post shared by Sonia Sanchez | GelX Nail Artist | 818 San Fernando Valley (@klawsbysonia) As we move into summer, experts agree that oranges and yellows are going to be hugely popular for manicures. â€œBold orange and energizing yellow colors will really liven up your manicure in 2025â€™s warmer months,â€ predicts Streets. But itâ€™s â€œcelestial yellowâ€ that she thinks is going to be everywhere. â€œInspired by otherworldly elements like the sun, moon and stars, itâ€™s one to add vibrancy to your nail look,â€ she says. Try OPI Nail Lacquer in Exotic Birds Do Not Tweet, $11.99, to recreate Sonia Sanchezâ€™s embellished citrus manicure at home. Subtle Chrome View this post on Instagram A post shared by @yo_keshh â€œChrome nails have been everywhere this year but I think they may start to feel overdone as we move into 2025,â€ says White. She predicts that rather than a â€œfull-coverage chrome finishâ€, weâ€™ll see a shift towards more subtle chrome accents and softer detailing for a more understated take on the trend. Keshiaâ€™s abstract gold chrome tips are the perfect example. Like what you see? title: 15 Fresh New Year Haircut Trends, Predicted By Top Stylists
description: .disclaimer{width:90%;margin-bottom:1rem}.disclaimer__lines{width:100%;margin:0 auto;border-bottom:1px solid #999;padding:0;max-width:150px}.disclaimer__copy{width:100%;max-width:355px;font-family:Brown Regular,sans-serif;font-size:.9rem;font-weight:300;line-height:1.3em;color:#333;padding:0 0 .4rem;margin:1rem auto;text-align:center} All linked products are independently selected by our editors. If you purchase any of these products, we may earn a commission. From the â€œkickedâ€ bob (an ultra-short crop with flicked out ends) to the â€œclaviâ€ cut (a mid-length chop that skims the clavicle or collarbone), we werenâ€™t short on haircut inspiration in 2024. But with a new year comes a fresh perspective â€” and countless more ways to wear our hair, too. If youâ€™re keen to switch things up this January, look no further. Ahead, we asked a handful of Londonâ€™s most sought-after hairstylists for their 2025 haircut predictions. Thereâ€™s something for everyone, whatever your hair type or texture. DashDividers_1_500x100 The Snack-Size Bob View this post on Instagram A post shared by Cassidy Gurev (@hairbycassidy_) Anita Rice, cofounder of Buller and Rice, says that the bob will live on in 2025 but itâ€™ll get even shorter. â€œThe snack-size bob, also known as the â€˜kickâ€™ bob, sits at the jawline and flicks out at the bottom,â€ Rice explains. â€œIt boasts blunt edges but thereâ€™s a lightly chopped texture [throughout] to add a little bit of versatility, so that you can flip around easily.â€ Rice suggests it works best with a side parting, slicked back with gel or mousse, or tucked behind the ears. The inspiration? Think musician LÃ¥psley, says Rice, or this cut posted to Instagram by hairstylist Cassidy Gurev of The Hair Bros.Â  The Boxie View this post on Instagram A post shared by Rubi (@poseandrepeat) The â€œbixieâ€, a cross between a bob and a pixie cut, is getting something of an upgrade for 2025. Enter: the â€œboxieâ€, which is a little longer and less maintenance, says James Bickmore, art director at Neil Moodie Studio. â€œItâ€™s perfect for those who are growing out a pixie but donâ€™t want a bob,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s easy to manage and gets better as it grows out. It has a very â€˜I woke up like thisâ€™ vibe â€” with a bit of an edge.â€ Take inspiration from content creator Rubi on Instagram. The Low Cut View this post on Instagram A post shared by barbie â„¢ (@loc._queen) Lorraine Dublin, a celebrity hairstylist, hair expert and educator, predicts that the â€œlowâ€ cut â€” as seen on Rihanna recently â€” is going to be a bold and beautiful hair statement in 2025. â€œThis style showcases how to elevate your natural curls while keeping things low maintenance,â€ says Dublin. â€œTo achieve this look, start by cutting your 4A curls to remove dead ends and any chemical treatments. Rihanna opts for a shorter length, but this style can also be customized with slightly longer layers for a softer look.â€ Keen to go even shorter? Look to model @loc._queen on Instagram. As for colou, Dublin says that golden tones add warmth and dimension, complementing the texture beautifully. â€œTo style, Iâ€™d recommend starting with a hydrating shampoo and conditioner, followed by a deep-conditioning mask,â€ says Dublin. â€œFenty Comeback Kid Leave-In Conditioner, $36, and Homecurl Curl Defining Cream, $28, are perfect for enhancing and shaping curls,â€ she adds. â€œUse your fingers or a wide-tooth comb to define the curls further, creating a polished yet effortless finish.â€ Bangs-Meets-Layers View this post on Instagram A post shared by G R A C E A M E L I A (@graceamelia___) If it isnâ€™t broken, donâ€™t fix it, suggests Zoe Adams, international artist at Taylor Taylor London. â€œ[Bangs] paired with layers is making a strong comeback for 2025, offering a soft and romantic aesthetic,â€ she says. â€œThe layered structure creates movement, while the bangs frame the face, adding definition and depth.â€ Even better, this style is ideal for most hair lengths, says Adams, but it works especially well for those with thicker hair looking to add lightness and shape. Anything goes, too. â€œCurtain bangs, wispy [bangs] or bold, blunt bangs can all complement layered cuts beautifully,â€ says Adams. This heavily layered cut by Grace Amelia hits the nail on the head. The Mixie â€™25 View this post on Instagram A post shared by Hair by Andy Judd (@andy_doesyourhair) Cut by Andy Judd, this mullet-meets-pixie on Addie Jean Carroll is the cut of 2025. â€œThe mixie is full of texture,â€ says Rice. â€œItâ€™s essentially an outgrown pixie with soft edges around the hairline, but length at the back can be kept longer to create a wolf cut variation.â€ According to Rice, the less styling, the better. â€œWear it natural for a â€˜bedheadâ€™ look,â€ she says. â€œConsider heavily texturized [bangs]; the length can be adjusted to your taste.â€ The Italian Bob 2.0 View this post on Instagram A post shared by Athisha Khan (@athishakhan) With both Bickmore and Adams singing its praises, the Italian bob is in no danger of becoming outdated, but thanks to the abundance of nifty hot brushes out there, weâ€™re going to play around with the size. Take a cue from this cut on Athisha Khan. Try the ghd Rise Professional Hot Brush, $167. Characterized by soft, subtle layers that sit just above the shoulders, Bickmore says the Italian bob offers the perfect balance of volume and movement. â€œItâ€™s effortlessly chic, low maintenance and works beautifully with natural textures, making it an ideal choice for those looking to combine style with ease,â€ he says. If your hair is on the fine side, Adams suggests asking your stylist for blunt ends to maximize the volume. â€œWhether styled sleek or with a soft wave, the Italian bob adds a touch of European elegance to any look,â€ she says. Triple XL Hair View this post on Instagram A post shared by Alyssa / curly hair friend â€ (@alyssarxs) XL = extra long Ã  la Charli xcx. â€œWeâ€™ve been seeing so much long long long hair (hence triple XL), and itâ€™s mostly worn with natural texture,â€ says Rice, like this cut on digital creator Alyssa. â€œAchieving this look wonâ€™t happen overnight but as weâ€™ve seen so many times on the catwalk or in editorials, you can opt for a little help from clip-in extensions.â€ And if your hair is naturally this long? Maintain it well, says Rice: â€œGet your hair cut regularly â€” every six to eight weeks â€” and invest in conditioning treatments.â€ Try Davines Nou Nou Hair Mask, $40. â€œIf your hair is [naturally wavy or curly], let it air-dry or diffuse and use a hair wand for extra waves if needed,â€ adds Rice. Try ghd Creative Curl Wand, $209. The Short Pixie Wig View this post on Instagram A post shared by G R A C E A M E L I A (@graceamelia___) If you donâ€™t want to brave the scissors, Dublin says that a short pixie wig is an excellent way to play with a new style and shade sans permanent change. â€œThis protective style allows you to enjoy a bold, cropped look without cutting or coloring your natural hair,â€ she says, pinpointing Leomie Anderson as inspiration. â€œWigs and extensions are also perfect for people who frequently change their hairstyles or need to protect their hair from damage,â€ she says. â€œIf youâ€™re looking for versatility and protection, this trend is a game-changer.â€ Look to digital creator Thai. Brow Bone Contouring View this post on Instagram A post shared by Q. (@callherrq) Bangs will become mini hairstyles in their own right, suggests hairstylist Tom Smith. â€œIn 2025 weâ€™ll see a variety of fusions of previously popular [bang] styles,â€ he tells R29. â€œBirkin bangs [inspired by the late Jane Birkin], bottleneck bangs [between curtain bangs and full bangs], curtain bangs, micro [bangs] and various other brow- and cheekbone-skimming lengths will be customized to frame the eyes with softly textured and choppy pieces.â€ â€œ[Bangs] like these are great for those who want something low-commitment because theyâ€™re softer and grow out gently, meaning they donâ€™t require regular trimming,â€ adds Smith. He suggests asking your stylist what would work best for your face shape: â€œ[This is important because theyâ€™ll] consider the size of your forehead, whether you want to show off your eyebrows or cheekbones and make sure youâ€™re willing to tweak the style every morning. Youâ€™ll need to reset this area of your hair every day, so while it can be done quickly, it does require some daily maintenance.â€ We love these face-framing bangs on digital creator Q. The Modern Curly Mullet View this post on Instagram A post shared by Tiff McColl ğŸ¸ğŸ§šğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸ğŸ’ ğŸ•ğŸ•â€ğŸ¦º âœ¨FREE PALESTINEğŸ‰ (@tiffmccoll) The mullet is making a major comeback, according to Dublin, and the modern iteration is made for those with curly hair. â€œ[Women with curls] are reimagining this iconic cut with their natural textures,â€ says Dublin. â€œThe look features shorter layers at the top and sides with longer, free-flowing curls at the back,â€ she adds, much like this style by hairstylist Tiff McColl. â€œThe shape enhances volume and movement, and itâ€™s perfect for those who want to push boundaries and pay homage to a style with rich cultural history while staying true to their natural hair pattern,â€ adds Dublin.Â She recommends adding a leave-in conditioner and a curl-enhancing cream to your hairstyling arsenal. Try Cantu Argan Oil Leave-In Conditioning Repair Cream, $6.48, and Living Proof Curl Enhancer, $51.50. Anti Bangs View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) â€œConsidering that weâ€™ve had so much interest in [bang] shapes over the past few years, I predict that 2025 is going to invite in [the opposite] in the form of elongated face-framing â€” no distinguishable layers or shaping around the face, but lengths that sit longer than the chin,â€ says Smith. Ryenne Snow nails it with this cut.Â The key to maintaining [bangs] like these is being kind on your strands. â€œAvoid splitting by turning down the heat on your tools and using a product like Olaplex No.3,â€ says Smith, which reduces breakage. â€œConcentrate it around the weaker hairline areas and be gentle when brushing,â€ he adds.
